House Burglarized—The home of

Mrs. Emma Holstiom, 2141 Royal, was
burglarized last evening between the
hours of 7 ard 10. The lost articles
include a Liberty Bond, $16 in cash
jewelry belonging to Mrs. Elizabeth
Holstrom, which amounted to $53 in
value. Entrance is thought to have
been gained by the front door afte

the robber had found the hiding place
of the key, according to the
who were notified immediately.

Outing—The annual outing the Dan-!
ish Lutheran church was held Satur- |
day afternoon at the Hermitage grove
The Ogden church was joined by}
members from the Salt Lake branch in
enjoying the outing |
There is no butter like B. & G

Relief Society—At a meeting of the)
Relief Society of Ogden Stake to be

speaker. Mrs. Gates is connected with |
the general board of relief societies
of the Mormon church with offices at
Salt Lake. All relief society workers
are invited to be present.
Renovated Arlington Hotel, manage-

ment R. A. Norris, special monthly
rates 1 or 2-room suites. 7112

Ogden Stake Outing—The Ogden
stake will hold an annual outing at

the Hermitage park in Ogden canyon, |
August 22, according to an announce: |
ment of the amusement committee.
The program for the -afternoon will}
consist of contests for young and old,!
as well as a dancing matinee for the)
children. The contests will include
swimming and boat races for both
boys and girls. Luncheon will be|
served from 6:30 until 8 p. m. The
rest of the evening will be occupied in|
dancing. |

Notebook containing the records of
the W. T. C. U. Red Cross unit has
been lost. Anyone finding please re-
turn Red Cross office, 5th floor, First
National bank Bldg. Phone 1200-J.

Stork Arrives—Mr. and Mrs. Herman |
Tival of a fine baby boy born to them
this morning at 9:15 o’clock at the
home, 2785 Grant avenue.

From Pocatello—R. A. Peirce, divi
sion superintendent of the Oregon
Short Line, with offices at Pocatello,
is in Ogden today.

From Promontory—Mrs. Leslie
Farr and Mrs. Stanley Farr of Prom-
ontory Point, spent Sunday with rela-
tives in Ogden.

Van Komen Case—A time for the |
hearing of William Van Komen was
not set this morning because of the
absence of an attorney from this city.
Van Komen is charged with -battery
by Leila Draney. This was the only
case before the municipal court this |
morning.

Boys Sent to Army—Out of 6350 boys |
in Ogden stake, 294 are now in the|
service of the country, according to|
the report of President T. B, Evans!
at the quarterly conference yesterday |
afternoon. The number of boys sent
by each ward is as follows: Sxith ward!
57; Fourth 56: Seventh 44: Huntsville |
43; Thirteenth 26; Kighth 24: North
Ogden 22: Eden 10; Middleton 6; Li-
berty 4; Pleasant View 2.

In France—Carl Allison received |
word this morning that his son, Ser- |
geant Leland B. Allison of Battery
B, had arrived in France. Six Allison
boys are now in the United States
service.

Safe in Camp—A telegram was re-
ceived by the city draft board today
from the contingent of men who left
last Friday, stating that they had ar-
rived safely at Camp Fremont, Cal.
The message was given by Ensign
Herrick, who was captain of the con-
tingent .

S. P, Outing—All Southern Pacific
employes are to have an outing at
Glenwood park on Saturday afternoon.

Wilford IE. Peters has proved that
persistence is usually the father of
attainment, for he has succeeded in

enlisting in the marines after being
rejected from Camp Lewis and turned
down in other places by examining of-
ficers

Peters was sent to Camp
March 2, 1918, with a contingent of
Ogden men who went to the army, but

was rejected for physical disqualifi- |
He tried again and again to,
finally made the marines,|Red Cross, had satisfied

OTANOARD FILING
Choo FOR BOARD

[he local draft board of county and
city will be equipped with standard |
filing cases for registration cards and |
for |
registration of men 18 to 45 becomes |
operatiye, according to information
sent them by E. H. Crowder, provost |
marshal general \

These cases have been made for lo- |
cal draft boards under government!
contract and will allow all boards to |
use the same filing system for their
| work, making the labor as efficient as

possible and giving a certain method
of keeping the record of each man
The local boards have been asked toa
base their requisition for cabinets on
the prospective registration.

SIX COLORED MEN |
HAVE BEEN REJECTED

Six of the colored registrants who
were sent to Camp Lewis a week ago
have been rejected for physical z

qualifications, according to informa-
tion sent to Ogden. The three last
reported are Leroy L. Johnson, Frank
P. Yieser and William H. Weakley.
The other three were reported several
days ago ,

William L. Maughan, Robert Hayes
and Nelson A. Williams have been ac-
cepted at Camp Lewis.
—oo0

BRITISH BATTLE
LINE 15 SECURE

Runs North to South and West |
Striking Old Line
Ribecourt. |

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY
FRANCE, Aug. 12:—2:16 p. m.—(By
the Associated Press..)—As nearly as
can be learned, the battle line from
north to south runs today near Meri-
court, Proyacourt, Raincourt and Li*
hons which apparently is finally seéure
in British hands after bitter fighting;
thence west of Chaulnes through or
near Chilly, which has changed hands
twice hence through Fouquescourt,
Parvillers, Damery, Andechy, L’Eche!l-
le, Armancourt, Dancourt, Popincourt, |
Roye-sur-Matz, Mareuil, Samson and
Antoval, striking the old line near
Ribecourt.

The battle appears to be approach -
ing the end of the first phase, with the
lines steadily hardening on the front.

The assistancg that has been ren-
dered by the Americans in this fight-
ing has been comparatively small but
nevertheless important, for they have
captured and held positions strongly
defended by the enemy at one of the
most difficult points in the line at a
time when the German resistance hera
was threatening to hold up the left
flank of the advance.

Lewis.

After being aroused from his slum-
bers at 3 a. m., Sunday morning, Rev.
J. E. Carver, president of the local
the wishes
of a train of soldiers which passed
through Ogden at 3:30 a. m, by se-

|}curing a guitar from the Gien Bros
Roberts Piano Co., and having’it at

the station for the soldiers when the
boys arrived.

The men were singing on the train
en route for France when one of the
|/men suggested that they should have

accompany the singing. The desires
of the men reached the captain in
j;charge of the train, who immediately |

wired to the chief dispatcher at Og-
den, asking if a guitar could be se
cured for the men. The dispatcher
immediately caNed Rev. Carver, tell-
ing him of the wants of the men and
{also the hour at which they were to; Mr. and Mrs
reach Ogden

By the time the men left Ogden,
they had some first class music, com-
ing from the strings of an Ogden gzui-
tar which, in all probability, will en-
tertain the men until they reach the
firing line.
The quick work of the Ogden Red
Cross officials shows that local chap- |
ters can work day and night.

Tracing Down the
Identity of
U-Boat Commander

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.—Investi-
gation by Commissioner Hugh M.
Smith of the bureau of fisheries has
failed to develop evidence to support
reports that the commander of the
German submarine which has _ been
sinking fishing ships off the New Eng-
land coast formerly was in the United
States fisheries service.

Commissioner Smith returned today
from Gloucester where he inquired
into the report: He said he found no
one who recognized the submarine
commander and that he had been in-
formed that a former navigator whose
Name was mentioned in the rumors
and whose wife lives in Gloucester has
been interned in Sweden
—oo

TEN PER CENT TAX
ON SOFT DRINKS

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.—A 10 per
cen, tax on all soft drinks sold by
manufacturer, producer, bottler or im-
portergand a tax;of from 1 to 2 cents
on soda fountain drinks were written
into the $8.000,000,000 revenue bill by
the house ways and means committee

The committee took the proprietary
and patent medicines out of the manu-
facturers’ 10 per cent tax and grouped
it in a 10. per cent stamp tax. -

Charming Ogden Girl
Becomes Bride of
Reverend Winters

Saturday evening at the home of
R. T. Smith, 2964 Grant
| Avenue a pretty wedding ceremony
;occurred when Miss Juanita Wallace,
accomplished daughter of Mr. and
Mrs. Smith became the bride of Rey
|G. M. Winters of Denver, Colo
| The wedding hour had been set for
/9:30 o'clock and promptly at this
time the bridal party entered the par-
dining room and parlor the ceremony
| Was performed by Rey. William Craw-) Mary

ford of the First Baptist church,
}and Mrs. Joseph Harris were

| sive wedding march
played by Mr. Ernest W. Jones.

The parlor of the Smith home was
ja veritable flower garden, a profusion
of white carnations, together with
vari-colored chrysanthemums and oth-
er summer flowers, being arranged in|

an artistic manner. Streamers of pink
and white were draped from the cen- |
tral chandelier to the four corners of
the room and created an exquisite
bower over the entire party The |
flowers were very prettily combined
with a variety of trailing ferns and
potted plants and were also used ef-
fectively on the porch where bright
Japanese lanters were strung. The
{lawn about the home was also pret-|
tily lighted with the lanterns and!
here the guests spent most of the |
levening following the wedding cere- |
mony. Japanese parasols were also
arranged in a unique manner on the} president of Utah Fraternal congress. |
